articles.headline: The Greener Guys
articles.snippet: Americans are increasingly identifying global warming as a serious problem, and a few companies are taking special steps to curb carbon emissions.
articles.abstract: Americans are increasingly identifying global warming as a serious problem, and a few companies are taking special steps to curb carbon emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Timberland, the outdoor clothing company, studied ways to reduce its carbon emissions four years ago, it weighed several options: building a wind farm in the Dominican Republic, buying power generated by renewable resources and setting up a vast bank of solar panels at one of its distribution centers in Ontario, Calif.

articles.headline: Anti-U.S. Rioting Erupts in Kabul; at Least 14 Dead
articles.snippet: A deadly accident caused by a U.S. military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown anti-American riot.
articles.abstract: A deadly accident caused by a U.S. military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown anti-American riot.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 29 — A deadly traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown antiAmerican riot on Monday that raged across much of the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured.

articles.headline: 2 at CBS News Die in Baghdad on Bloody Day
articles.snippet: The police said at least 31 other people were killed in one of the worst days of bloodshed in the Iraqi capital in weeks.
articles.abstract: The police said at least 31 other people were killed in one of the worst days of bloodshed in the Iraqi capital in weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 29  On a day of soaring violence in Baghdad, two Britons working as members of a CBS News television crew were killed on Monday and an American correspondent for the network was critically wounded when a military patrol they were accompanying was hit by a roadside bomb.

articles.headline: Technology and Easy Credit Give Identity Thieves an Edge
articles.snippet: One in six adults in Arizona had their identities stolen in the last five years, about twice the national rate.
articles.abstract: One in six adults in Arizona had their identities stolen in the last five years, about twice the national rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a Scottsdale police station last December, a 23-year-old methamphetamine user showed officers a new way to steal identities.
articles.byline: By John Leland and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: Cell Carriers Seek Growth by Catering to Hispanics
articles.snippet: The industry is spending tens of millions of dollars on marketing campaigns to court Hispanic customers.
articles.abstract: The industry is spending tens of millions of dollars on marketing campaigns to court Hispanic customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 — Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Holiday Travelers Hit the Road, but Scrimped a Bit
articles.snippet: As the summer travel season began, many Americans said they were looking for ways to cut their spending.
articles.abstract: As the summer travel season began, many Americans said they were looking for ways to cut their spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pam and Matt Keith spent Memorial Day weekend on a houseboat on Lake Oroville in Northern California. But because of high gasoline prices, the Keiths never even untied the boat from its mooring slightly offshore. When they ventured away from the shore, they supplied their own power — in kayaks.

articles.headline: Gas Giant Gets Offer for Buyout
articles.snippet: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer Monday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc.
articles.abstract: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer Monday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer yesterday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: The Greener Guys
articles.snippet: When Timberland, the outdoor clothing company, studied ways to reduce its carbon emissions four years ago, it weighed several options: building a wind farm in the Dominican Republic, buying power generated by renewable resources and setting up a v...
articles.abstract: When Timberland, the outdoor clothing company, studied ways to reduce its carbon emissions four years ago, it weighed several options: building a wind farm in the Dominican Republic, buying power generated by renewable resources and setting up a vast bank of solar panels at one of its distribution centers in Ontario, Calif.      It chose to do all those things, but that was the easy part. When Jeffrey B. Swartz, Timberland's president and chief executive, considered how much carbon dioxide was produced in making leather for the company's famous boots, the answer came as a surprise.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Timberland, the outdoor clothing company, studied ways to reduce its carbon emissions four years ago, it weighed several options: building a wind farm in the Dominican Republic, buying power generated by renewable resources and setting up a vast bank of solar panels at one of its distribution centers in Ontario, Calif.

articles.headline: Gas Giant Gets Offer for Buyout
articles.snippet: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer yesterday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997.      The deal, which includes the assumption of about $8 billion in debt, would ...
articles.abstract: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer yesterday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997.      The deal, which includes the assumption of about $8 billion in debt, would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company bought RJR Nabisco in 1989 for $25 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer yesterday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: U.S. Is Sending Reserve Troops to Iraq's West
articles.snippet: The top American commander in Iraq has decided to move reserve troops now deployed in Kuwait into the volatile Anbar Province in western Iraq to help quell a rise in insurgent attacks there, two American officials said Monday.     Although some so...
articles.abstract: The top American commander in Iraq has decided to move reserve troops now deployed in Kuwait into the volatile Anbar Province in western Iraq to help quell a rise in insurgent attacks there, two American officials said Monday.     Although some soldiers from the 3,500-member brigade in Kuwait have moved into Iraq in recent months, Gen. George W. Casey Jr. has decided to send in the remainder of the unit after consultations with Iraqi officials in recent days, the officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 29 - The top American commander in Iraq has decided to move reserve troops now deployed in Kuwait into the volatile Anbar Province in western Iraq to help quell a rise in insurgent attacks there, two American officials said Monday.

articles.headline: Talk of Pelosi as Speaker Delights Both Parties
articles.snippet: Hoping to win a Congressional majority in November, some optimistic Democratic lawmakers have taken to referring to Representative Nancy Pelosi as ''speaker,'' as in speaker of the House. So have some optimistic Republicans.     ''She ought to be ...
articles.abstract: Hoping to win a Congressional majority in November, some optimistic Democratic lawmakers have taken to referring to Representative Nancy Pelosi as ''speaker,'' as in speaker of the House. So have some optimistic Republicans.     ''She ought to be a big component of the fall campaign,'' said Ed Rogers, a Republican strategist and lobbyist. ''There are some Democrats who make really good bad guys.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 29 - Hoping to win a Congressional majority in November, some optimistic Democratic lawmakers have taken to referring to Representative Nancy Pelosi as "speaker," as in speaker of the House. So have some optimistic Republicans.

articles.headline: Cell Carriers Seek Growth by Catering to Hispanics
articles.snippet: Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics.    ...
articles.abstract: Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics.     The industry is spending tens of millions of dollars on marketing campaigns to court Hispanic customers. This summer, Verizon is sponsoring the concert tour of the Colombian-born pop singer Shakira, while Sprint is promoting advanced phones that let subscribers watch television and download songs in Spanish.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 - Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Anti-U.S. Rioting Erupts in Kabul; at Least 14 Dead
articles.snippet: A deadly traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown antiAmerican riot on Monday that raged across much of the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured.      Witnesses said ...
articles.abstract: A deadly traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown antiAmerican riot on Monday that raged across much of the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured.      Witnesses said American soldiers fired on Afghans throwing stones at them after the crash, though the United States military said only that warning shots had been fired in the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 29 - A deadly traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown antiAmerican riot on Monday that raged across much of the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured.

articles.headline: Holiday Travelers Hit the Road, but Scrimped a Bit
articles.snippet: Pam and Matt Keith spent Memorial Day weekend on a houseboat on Lake Oroville in Northern California. But because of high gasoline prices, the Keiths never even untied the boat from its mooring slightly offshore. When they ventured away from the s...
articles.abstract: Pam and Matt Keith spent Memorial Day weekend on a houseboat on Lake Oroville in Northern California. But because of high gasoline prices, the Keiths never even untied the boat from its mooring slightly offshore. When they ventured away from the shore, they supplied their own power -- in kayaks.     It is a summer of restraint for the Keiths. They are trying to increase their savings, and to reach their goal, they canceled a weeklong trip later this summer to Maui, where they had planned to celebrate Ms. Keith's graduation from business school.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pam and Matt Keith spent Memorial Day weekend on a houseboat on Lake Oroville in Northern California. But because of high gasoline prices, the Keiths never even untied the boat from its mooring slightly offshore. When they ventured away from the shore, they supplied their own power -- in kayaks.

articles.headline: Poisonous Tree Frog Could Bring Wealth to Tribe in Brazilian Amazon
articles.snippet: Fernando Katukina is chief of an indigenous tribe that lives largely without running water, electricity, or links to the world outside this remote corner of the western Amazon.     But Chief Fernando says he possesses a treasure that could be at t...
articles.abstract: Fernando Katukina is chief of an indigenous tribe that lives largely without running water, electricity, or links to the world outside this remote corner of the western Amazon.     But Chief Fernando says he possesses a treasure that could be at the cutting-edge of biotechnology. If a plan initiated by the chief is successful, his tribe's fortunes will be transformed by an asset he and the Brazilian government believe holds great promise for the global pharmaceutical industry: the slime from a poisonous tree frog.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMPINAS INDIAN RESERVE, Brazil - Fernando Katukina is chief of an indigenous tribe that lives largely without running water, electricity, or links to the world outside this remote corner of the western Amazon.

articles.headline: Venezuela Seeks to Cut Oil Output
articles.snippet: When President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela wraps up this week's meeting of OPEC's 11 members in Caracas with an excursion for delegates to Canaima National Park, the location of the world's tallest waterfall, it will be another chance to remind energ...
articles.abstract: When President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela wraps up this week's meeting of OPEC's 11 members in Caracas with an excursion for delegates to Canaima National Park, the location of the world's tallest waterfall, it will be another chance to remind energy markets of his influence in helping drive oil prices above $70 a barrel.      Of course, most delegates to the Thursday meeting are expected to nod politely to Venezuela's calls for output cuts that could drive prices even higher, while doing the opposite by reaping all they can from the current bonanza of high prices. The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates rejected talk on Monday of a possible cut in the cartel's output quotas of 28 million barrels a day.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 29 - When President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela wraps up this week's meeting of OPEC's 11 members in Caracas with an excursion for delegates to Canaima National Park, the location of the world's tallest waterfall, it will be another chance to remind energy markets of his influence in helping drive oil prices above $70 a barrel.

articles.headline: Technology and Easy Credit Give Identity Thieves an Edge
articles.snippet: In a Scottsdale police station last December, a 23-year-old methamphetamine user showed officers a new way to steal identities.      His arrest had been unremarkable. This metropolitan area, which includes Scottsdale and Phoenix, has the highest r...
articles.abstract: In a Scottsdale police station last December, a 23-year-old methamphetamine user showed officers a new way to steal identities.      His arrest had been unremarkable. This metropolitan area, which includes Scottsdale and Phoenix, has the highest rate of identity theft complaints in the nation, according to the Federal Trade Commission. Even members of the Scottsdale police force have had their identities stolen.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX - In a Scottsdale police station last December, a 23-year-old methamphetamine user showed officers a new way to steal identities.
articles.byline: By John Leland and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: Can't Complete High School? Go Right to College
articles.snippet: It is a kind of Alice-in-Wonderland idea. If you do not finish high school, head straight for college.      But many colleges -- public and private, two-year and four-year -- will accept students who have not graduated from high school or earned e...
articles.abstract: It is a kind of Alice-in-Wonderland idea. If you do not finish high school, head straight for college.      But many colleges -- public and private, two-year and four-year -- will accept students who have not graduated from high school or earned equivalency degrees.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a kind of Alice-in-Wonderland idea. If you do not finish high school, head straight for college.
